choices.text: Congo red is the commonest stain used for diagnosis
Electron microscopy shows non branching fibrils
Apple green birefringence with PAS staining

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with numbness and tingling in his hands and feet. He also reports weakness and difficulty walking. Examination reveals enlarged tongue, carpal tunnel syndrome, and a waddling gait. Biopsy of the sural nerve shows deposits of amyloid protein. Which of the following is not correct about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Apple green birefringence with PAS staining

 

Option D:

 

This is the incorrect statement. PAS (Periodic Acid-Schiff) staining is used to detect polysaccharides, mucosubstances, and glycoproteins in tissues. Amyloid is not positive with PAS staining; instead, it is the Congo red staining that demonstrates apple green birefringence under polarized light. PAS staining usually shows amyloid as a magenta or pink color.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Congo red staining is indeed the most common method used for the diagnosis of amyloidosis. When viewed under polarized light, amyloid deposits stained with Congo red show a characteristic apple green birefringence.

 

Option B. Electron microscopy of amyloid fibrils typically shows non-branching, linear fibrils. This is due to the beta-pleated sheet configuration of the proteins that make up the fibrils, which is a hallmark of amyloid deposits.

 

Option C. On spectroscopy, the beta-pleated sheet conformation of the amyloid fibrils results in a distinct pattern. This structure is stable and resistant to proteolysis, which is why amyloid deposits are typically insoluble and accumulate in various tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amyloid deposits do not exhibit apple green birefringence when stained with PAS; this characteristic is observed with Congo red staining under polarized light.

 

  • Apple green birefringence is seen with Congo red under polarised light

 

Robbins 10th/259

choices.text: Accumulation of amyloid proteins in the extracellular space
Accumulation of amyloid proteins in the intracellular space
Accumulation of amyloid proteins in the cytoplasmic space
Accumulation of amyloid proteins in the mitochondrial space

questions.text: In a patient with progressive fatigue, kidney dysfunction, and an echocardiogram suggesting restrictive cardiomyopathy, a biopsy is performed, and the pathologist observes eosinophilic, fibrillary material in the tissue that stains with Congo red. This finding is most consistent with which pattern of protein accumulation in amyloidosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accumulation of amyloid proteins in the extracellular space

 

Option A:

  • Amyloidosis is a disorder characterized by the abnormal accumulation of insoluble, fibrous protein aggregates known as amyloid fibrils. These fibrils deposit in various tissues and organs, leading to organ dysfunction. The accumulation of amyloid proteins occurs primarily in the extracellular space, causing disruption of tissue architecture and function.

Explanation :

Option B: intracellular accumulation of amyloid proteins, is not a key feature of amyloidosis.

Option C and D: accumulation of amyloid proteins in the cytoplasmic and mitochondrial space, respectively, are also not key features of amyloidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

The key feature of amyloidosis is the extracellular accumulation of amyloid proteins, which can lead to a range of clinical manifestations depending on the organs affected.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic inflammatory disease presents with fatigue, weight loss, and edema. Physical examination reveals macroglossia and periorbital purpura. Laboratory studies show renal insufficiency and proteinuria. To confirm the suspected diagnosis of amyloidosis, which of the following diagnostic tests should be performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Biopsy of affected tissue

Option D:

Explanation:

  • A definitive diagnosis of amyloidosis requires a biopsy of affected tissue, such as the skin, kidney, liver, or gastrointestinal tract.
  • The biopsy specimen is examined under a microscope to identify the presence of amyloid fibrils. Additional tests, such as immunohistochemistry, mass spectrometry, or electron microscopy, may be used to determine the specific type of amyloid protein involved.

 

Educational Objective:

Biopsy of affected tissue is the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis of amyloidosis. It involves taking a sample from affected organs like the kidney, liver, or gastrointestinal tract and identifying amyloid fibrils under a microscope with additional confirmatory tests such as immunohistochemistry or electron microscopy.
